title: @Riot can you finally make a champion i like
body: The last champion you released that i enjoy was lissandra which was 3 years ago.. You need to make more mages idk why we needed two adc in a row basically

replies.body:
Generally we prefer to avoid making two of the same class in quick succession. In this case though we felt Kindred was an unusual case, since they're generally strongest in a position many marksmen players won't play. Kalista was the marksman before that, and she's got a playstyle that can be pretty love it or hate it too. We felt there was a good case for another marksman in the spot after Illaoi as a result, feeling there were a significant number of players who hadn't had a marksman that worked for them since Jinx. 

As far as mages go we're with you though that, depending on what type of mage you like, it may have been a very long time since a new mage came out that fit your playstyle too (traditional caster types, rather than hybrids like Azir). We concluded getting a true caster mage into the lineup for 2016 was important as a result, and have one under development at the moment. Not appropriate to say anything about timeframe besides 'definitely this year' yet, working actively on filling the need for such a champ though.

>As far as mages go we're with you though that, depending on what type of mage you like, it may have been a very long time since a new mage came out that fit your playstyle too 

As someone who mostly plays mages and jungle tanks I can honestly say champion releases have felt very underwhelming to me over the last two years. Even before that, in 2013 they weren't that great.

The last champ I fell in love with on release was Elise way back in 2012. Before Elise I often enjoyed new champion releases. Champions with kits I found fun were released with a fairly high frequency. I loved Syndra and Zyra especially. 

So here's the question, where's the champions for people like me? People who don't want excessively complex champions like the ones who have been released since Vel'koz and Braum. It feels like you're overly catering to one portion of the community while completely ignoring another. 

Even Jihn doesn't look like what I'm talking about to be honest. He's better than most recent champs but he's still actually very complex when compared to the likes of the champs I was mentioning. He has 4 passives for example.

I guess what I'm asking is if we can expect to see more champions who derive their power and interest from how their abilities interact rather than just quantity of abilities and passives or raw power in individual abilities.

Agreed, I want to see more champions with Garen's level of complexity. A simple and straight-forward kit you understand at first glance, rather than reading the skills multiple times to get a complete fix on what the champion's about.

I'll speak to that a little because I made one of them (Azir).

I think these three are all cool champions, but none of them satisfy the desire for a traditional mid-lane mage. Let's go through them:

Ekko: Ekko's a melee assassin. He does have one ability that feels like midlane mage (Q), but the rest of him is so positioning-reliant and he has to put his body on the line to get pay off so much, he really doesn't feel like a traditional mage.

Azir: One of the goals with Azir was specifically not to make a traditional mage. We wanted to make something new and halfway through we decided he might live somewhere between a mage and a marksman, and that's cool and unique, but again does not satisfy the desire for a new traditional mage.

Vel'Koz: Professor Eyebeam comes closest to traditional midlane mage in terms of his spells (they all feel VERY magey) and overall damage profile, but thanks to his passive and his generous base damages (and less than stellar scalings), he doesn't need to go mid and is perfectly happy as a support. The play pattern is right, but if the optimal position in the current meta isn't mid, it's not a traditional mid lane mage.

Wish us luck. Making an old-school champ is actually quite hard.
I Ekko really an assassin? He just feels more like an AP fighter than anything.

>Wish us luck. Making an old-school champ is actually quite hard.

That's because you use Thresh as a gold standard for what a champ should be like. Take a step back and look at older champions and what makes their kits unique.

I think Syndra is one of the best examples of champion design in the game. You should take a look at what it is that makes her work.

Her abilities are individually very weak, amongst the weakest in the game. In a game mode where you could only skill one ability Syndra would be one of the weakest champs regardless of which one she skilled. Syndra's strength comes entirely from her combos and the interaction of her abilities. It gives her kit a sense of flow and levels of mastery that have been lacking in recent champions even though her kit is very simple when you break it down spell for spell.

The problem with your recent champions (at least as a traditional mage) is that you too much power into single spells now. Recent champs don't have a spell which individually does very little but which interacts with their other spells in such a way as to create more interesting gameplay for them like a Dark Sphere, Command: Attack or Rampant Growth because all their spells have so much power that doing so would absolutely break the champion.

If you want to design a good traditional mage you have to be willing to give them weak spells which interact with each other in order to create the champions gameplay. You have to be willing to give up the "Every spell is impactfull" philosophy that seems to have evolved since Thresh. I'd actually say Azir is one of the better 'recent' champs at this but as you said, the goal wasn't really to create a traditional mage.
